thread.title: At work and at play in Chincoteague
thread.title_full: At work and at play in Chincoteague

author: wlohmann@timesdispatch.com(Bill Lohmann)
title: At work and at play in Chincoteague
text:
BOB BROWN 20150719_FLR_CHINCO_BB20 
A boat pulls away from the pier at Robert N. Reed Downtown Waterfront Park in Chincoteague, VA Wednesday, June17, 2015. Related Galleries 
A visit to Chincoteague Island on Virginia's Eastern Shore reveals many things to see besides the annual pony penning. ADVERTISEMENT Posted: Saturday, July 25, 2015 10:30 pm At work and at play in Chincoteague PHOTOS BY BOB BROWN AND STORY BY BILL LOHMANN Richmond Times-Dispatch Richmond Times-Dispatch 
The annual Chincoteague Pony Swim will be held Wednesday, the 90th year of the event made famous by Marguerite Henry’s “Misty of Chincoteague.” 
Make no mistake: This island on the Eastern Shore is all about ponies, from statues on the waterfront to the real things at the Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge. But a recent visit to Chincoteague — 190 miles from Richmond via Interstate 64 and a $15 ride across the Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel — revealed more than ponies. The revelations included Zack, a blue-and-gold macaw who lives in a large outdoor cage in the summer and come evening usually will start “singing, dancing and carrying on,” said owner Deborah Harley. He particularly likes it when bicyclists pedal along the otherwise quiet road. Subscription Required An online service is needed to view this article in its entirety.
